newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian Broadcasting Corp Midday Update.
newsitem.headline: Australian Broadcasting Corp Midday Update.

text.p: GOVT INTENSIFIES COLSTON ATTACK
The Acting Opposition Leader, Gareth Evans, says the Government's defence of Senator Mal Colston's elevation to Acting Senate President is a charade.
Mr Evans says there's no need for a police investigation or conviction to establish a rock-solid prima face case demanding political accountability.
Senator Colston, who's the Deputy President, is Acting Senate President while Margaret Reid is overseas, despite an ongoing investigation into his use of travel allowances.
HANSON MEETING DRAWS 200 SUPPORTERS
An audience member at Pauline Hanson's meeting in the Northern Territory last night called for single mothers on welfare to be desexed.
Another wanted Aborigines to pay a fee to travel off their traditional lands.
The audience cheered most of the Independent Ferederal MPs views including her call for an end to immigration and benefits for single mothers who sponge off the welfare system.
There was also support for her view that too much land has been handed back to Aboriginal people.
About 200 people attended the meeting in Humpty Doo, south-west of Darwin.
STADIUM CONFIDENT PASSES WILL BE SOLD
The builders of Sydney's Olympic Stadium say they're confident the remaining available gold passes in the Stadium float will sold, and have assured existing seat holders they won't be discounted.

Stadium Australia attempted to raise over three-hundred-million dollars through the sale of gold Olympic packages at 10-thousand dollars each, but has come up with a two-hundred-million dollar shortfall.
Chairman, Peter Richie, told ABC Radio only 40-per cent of gold seats for the Games have been sold.
Mr Richie says while the stadium's underwriters were over-confident about the float, he expects the remaining 20-thousand passes will be sold.
MEETING TO DISCUSS GOLD ROYALTY
In Western Australia, a public meeting is to be held in Kalgoorlie on the State Government's proposed gold royalty.
Premier Richard Court and State opposition leader, Geoff Gallop, have been invited to address the meeting.
Representatives from the mining industry and the town's Chamber of Commerce will also speak at the meeting.

The chief executive of the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies, George Savell, says it will not be a protest meeting, but an opportunity to let the people directly involved in the industry know what impact a royalty will have.
Mr Savell says the Government has not thought about the effect a royalty will have on regional mining towns.
The public meeting will be held on April the 17th.
HOT BREAD SHOP TO BE PROSECUTED
A Melbourne hot bread shop allegedly linked to a food contamination outbreak will be prosecuted.
A writ filed in the Federal Court today seeks unspecified damages from Star World Enterprises, a company trading as the World Hot Bread Bakery in Springvale.
The proposed class action has been initiated after more than 50 people registered their interst in legal action against the bakery.
More than 300 people sought hospital treatment last month after suffering gastro-enteritis allegedly linked to the shop.
NEW MANAGEMENT PRACTICES COULD HAVE LED TO RIOT
Queensland's Corrective Services Minister Russel Cooper says he wants new management practices introduced at Woodford Prison to continue, despite last night's riot.

Corrective Services Commisioner Keith Hamburger says the Commission's introduced a policy which encourages prison officers to interact more with prisoners, enabling staff to observe prisoners more closely and get on top of any problems that arise.
He admits it may have contributed to the riot, and says it seems some inmates don't like staff in their space.
But Mr Cooper says the Government won't be backing off because of resistance from a few prisoners.
NO SUBMISSION BY FOREIGN AFFAIRS ON RA

The chairman of the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee says considers it a serious ommission by the Department of Foreign Affairs not to have forwarded a formal submission on the future of ABC's Radio Australia and Australia Television.

A first assistant secretary of the Foreign Affairs Department, Bill Fisher, told the Senate committee there was no written submission because Radio Australia's future is being considered by the Government.
Michael Forshaw, said the inquiry would press the Foreign Affairs Minister for a submission, describing it as more than disappointing. - - - -
VIC OPPOSITION ON THE ATTACK OVER FELICITY'S BMW
The Victorian Opposition has gone on the attack in Parliament over BMW's gift of a car to the Premier's wife, Felicity Kennett.
The Shadow Attorney General, Rob Hulls, has alleged the gift could have been a direct payback for Mr Kennett opening an exclusive BMW dealership at Southbank, in Melbourne, last year.
He's also questioned Mr Kennett's promotion of Crown Casino, saying Crown gives away 250 BMW's a year.
Mr Hulls says BMW paid for the Premier's private suite at this year's Australian Grand Prix, and donated to the Liberal Party at the last State Election.
He's accused Mr Kennett of blatantly using his office for private gain, and says the Premier must explain his role in the BMW Affair.
